subject: RE: [junit] How to test protected and private methods/ fields?

messageBody:
Q. What are we trying to do when we do "unit" testing?
A. We are testing all of the interfaces exposed by a "unit" to external
components to ensure that those interfaces react as we would expect them to
in all reasonable scenarios that we can think of.

So to answer the question about private/protected methods: Does a private
method expose itself to external components? No - therefore we do not need
to test them. Errors within private methods will become apparent from
testing the other interfaces.

Do we need to test protected methods? Yes - protected methods are accessible
external to the unit and therefore form part of that unit's interface. If
you are going to call protected methods there are four ways that you could
do it that I can think of:
a)Subclass the class you are testing
b)Use reflection
c)Don't use protected methods, always use public
d)Place the test code in the same package

Option "a" is a bit icky, and will only work in certain situations anyway
(how do you test a "final" class? Java only has single inheritance so how do
you extend TestCase as well...etc). Option "b" will work but is also icky -
and a sledgehammer to crack a nut. Option "c" will work but I would always
be loathe to do it. My instinct is always to place as much restriction as
possible on a method (the more I expose the more I have to maintain and the
higher coupling I could potentially have). Option "d" will work and is the
simplest to do.

I recommend option d. As has been previously suggested I always place my
test code in the same package but a separate directory to maintain
separation of the two things.

Matt

use
JUnit for writing unittests. But I have a question which I hope some of
you
can help me with - it's regarding testing private/protected methods and
how
to organize my test package.

First the package. I have read to articles regarding test ("Junit best
practices" from JavaWorld and "Incremental development with Ant and
JUnit"
from developerWorks). In the JBT article Andy Schneider advice you to
keep
tests in the same location as the source code. And in the Incremental...
article Malcolm Davis advice you to make a separate package. Which
approach
is the best to use?

I must admit that I like the idea of making a separate package but then
again - how do I then test private and protected methods? And if I keep
the
tests in the same location as the source code - who do I then test
private
methods?

I would very much appreciate if some of you could give me a little
example

Kind regards,
